data.value: Create a memory-map to an array stored in a *binary* file on disk.
Memory-mapped files are used for accessing small segments of large files on disk, without reading the entire file into memory.  NumPy's memmap's are array-like objects.  This differs from Python's
module, which uses file-like objects.
This subclass of ndarray has some unpleasant interactions with some operations, because it doesn't quite fit properly as a subclass. An alternative to using this subclass is to create the
object yourself, then create an ndarray with ndarray.__new__ directly, passing the object created in its 'buffer=' parameter.
This class may at some point be turned into a factory function which returns a view into an mmap buffer.
Flush the memmap instance to write the changes to the file. Currently there is no API to close the underlying
. It is tricky to ensure the resource is actually closed, since it may be shared between different memmap instances.

data.type_: str, file-like object, or pathlib.Path instance

data.value: The file name or file object to be used as the array data buffer.
The data-type used to interpret the file contents. Default is
The file is opened in this mode:
Default is 'r+'.
In the file, array data starts at this offset. Since
is measured in bytes, it should normally be a multiple of the byte-size of
. When
, even positive offsets beyond end of file are valid; The file will be extended to accommodate the additional data. By default,
will start at the beginning of the file, even if
is a file pointer
and
The desired shape of the array. If
and the number of remaining bytes after
is not a multiple of the byte-size of
, you must specify
. By default, the returned array will be 1-D with the number of elements determined by file size and data-type.
Specify the order of the ndarray memory layout
, C-style or
, Fortran-style.  This only has an effect if the shape is greater than 1-D.  The default order is 'C'.
Path to the mapped file.
Offset position in the file.
File mode.
Flush any changes in memory to file on disk. When you delete a memmap object, flush is called first to write changes to disk.
The memmap object can be used anywhere an ndarray is accepted. Given a memmap
returns
Memory-mapped files cannot be larger than 2GB on 32-bit systems.

When a memmap causes a file to be created or extended beyond its current size in the filesystem, the contents of the new part are unspecified. On systems with POSIX filesystem semantics, the extended part will be filled with zero bytes.
This example uses a temporary file so that doctest doesn't write files to your directory. You would use a 'normal' filename.
